elements.content: Stoichiometric 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles have been synthesized from thermal decomposition of a new molecular heterometallic precursor [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]·3/2H2O whose crystal structure has been solved by single crystal X-ray diffraction. From this precursor, highly homogeneous 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles, with average particle size of 70 nm, are obtained. The agglomeration of these nanoparticles maintains the sheet-assembling morphology of the metal–organic compound. Local structural information, provided by atomically resolved microscopy techniques, shows that 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles exhibit the same general structural features as the bulk material, although structural disorder, due to edge dislocations, is observed. The nanometric particle size enables a topotactic reduction process at low temperature stabilizing a metastable 4H-SrMnO2.82 phase. The oxygen deficiency is accommodated through extra cubic layers breaking the ...chch... 4H-sequence. These defect areas are Mn3+ rich, as evidenced by high energy resolution EELS data. Magnetic characterization of nano-SrMnO3.0 shows significant variations with respect to the bulk material. Besides the dominant antiferromagnetic interactions, a weak ferromagnetic contribution as well as exchange bias and a glassy-like component are present. After the reduction process, the stabilization of Mn3+ in the 4H-structure gives rise to magnetic anomalies in the 40–60 K temperature range. The origin of such magnetic features is discussed.

The agglomeration of these nanoparticles maintains the sheet-assembling morphology of the metal-organic compound. Local structural information, provided by atomically resolved microscopy techniques, shows that 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles exhibit the same general structural features as the bulk material, although structural disorder, due to edge dislocations, is observed. The nanometric particle size enables a topotactic reduction process at low temperature stabilizing a metastable 4H-SrMnO2.82 phase. The oxygen deficiency is accommodated through extra cubic layers breaking the ...chch... 4H-sequence. These defect areas are Mn3+ rich, as evidenced by high energy resolution EELS data. After the reduction process, the stabilization of Mn3+ in the 4H-structure gives rise to magnetic anomalies in the 40-60 K temperature range. The origin of such magnetic features is discussed.

elements.content: The current demand of technological devices requires the continuous preparation of new compounds at the nanometer scale in such a way that their chemical and physical properties must allow the development of novel applications. Particular attention has been paid to perovskite related mixed oxides due to the huge diversity of their functional properties making them ideal candidates to study the effect of particle size reduction. Among them, nanomanganates constitute a promising system as a result of the structural variety and outstanding properties found in their bulk counterparts. The ability of Mn to adopt mixed oxidation states allows many combinations of chemical doping and anion vacancies to be accommodated leading, in turn, to structures with different dimensionality and with interplay among spin, charge and orbital degrees of freedom. Thus, diverse and fascinating properties are found in this rich variety of oxides: colossal magnetoresistance in La1–x A′ x MnO3 (A′ = alkaline earth), high permittivity in BaMn0.5Ti0.5O3, multiferroic behavior, and large nonlinear optical response in BiMnO3, giant magneto-elastic coupling in multiferroic hexagonal manganates, etc.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The current demand of technological devices requires the continuous preparation of new compounds at the nanometer scale in such a way that their chemical and physical properties must allow the development of novel applications. Particular attention has been paid to perovskite related mixed oxides due to the huge diversity of their functional properties making them ideal candidates to study the effect of particle size reduction. Among them, nanomanganates constitute a promising system as a result of the structural variety and outstanding properties found in their bulk counterparts. The ability of Mn to adopt mixed oxidation states allows many combinations of chemical doping and anion vacancies to be accommodated leading, in turn, to structures with different dimensionality and with interplay among spin, charge and orbital degrees of freedom. Thus, diverse and fascinating properties are found in this rich variety of oxides: colossal magnetoresistance in La1-x A' x MnO3 (A' = alkaline earth), high permittivity in BaMn0.5Ti0.5O3, multiferroic behavior, and large nonlinear optical response in BiMnO3, giant magneto-elastic coupling in multiferroic hexagonal manganates, etc.

elements.content: Regarding the ability of the perovskite structure to adopt several polytypes, particular interest has been focused on materials based on the ordered intergrowth between the 3C- and 2H-ABO3 structural types, which represent the two ‘extreme’ polytypes of the perovskite structure. The first one is based only on cubic close packed (...ccp...) AO3 layers. The structure, which consists of a 3D array of corner-sharing BO6 octahedra, is stable when the structural tolerance factor t is close to one (t = d A‑O/√2·d B–O, where d A‑O and d B–O represent the average cation–oxygen interatomic distances of the A- and B-sites, respectively). In contrast, the unit cell of the 2H-type consists of two AO3 layers in a hexagonal close packed (...hcp...) sequence, producing a structure formed by 1D chains of face-sharing BO6 octahedra parallel to the c-axis. This structural variety is stabilized for high t values (t > 1). Between these two extremes, numerous intermediate structures are known to exist, with different degrees of cubic (c) and hexagonal (h) layers.

The structure, which consists of a 3D array of corner-sharing BO6 octahedra, is stable when the structural tolerance factor t is close to one (t = d A-O/√2⋅d B-O, where d A-O and d B-O represent the average cation-oxygen interatomic distances of the A- and B-sites, respectively). In contrast, the unit cell of the 2H-type consists of two AO3 layers in a hexagonal close packed (...hcp...) sequence, producing a structure formed by 1D chains of face-sharing BO6 octahedra parallel to the c-axis. This structural variety is stabilized for high t values (t > 1). Between these two extremes, numerous intermediate structures are known to exist, with different degrees of cubic (c) and hexagonal (h) layers.

elements.content: We have recently reported the hydrothermal synthesis of single crystalline 2H-BaMnO3 nanoparticles. The optimization of parameters governing this synthesis procedure has permitted the preparation of monodispersed nanoparticles with minimum size in the range 10–40 nm. To date, this work constitutes the only example of a nanosized A′BO3 (A′ = alkaline earth) hexagonal perovskite, and we have treated to extend this study to the preparation of 4H-SrMnO3 nanoparticles, where hexagonal and cubic layers alternate along the c-axis, providing a (...hchc...) sequence.

elements.content: Spooren and Walton reported the first successful hydrothermal synthesis of 4H-SrMnO3 but the resulting morphology was rather heterogeneous ranging from elongated prismatic microcrystals to microparticles. More recently, Zhu et al. have shown the influence of the starting materials in the morphology of the SrMnO3 particles obtained from hydrothermal conditions, forming rhombus-like shaped crystals when KMnO4, Mn(CH3COO)2 and Sr(CH3COO)2 were used as starting materials, and rod-like particles when synthesized from KMnO4, MnSO4 and SrSO4, but no SrMnO3 nanoparticles were attained. Moreover, Rizzuti et al obtained blade-shaped particles of 4H-SrMnO3 by microwave assisted hydrothermal synthesis although still in the microscale.

elements.content: To prepare 4H-SrMnO3 nanoparticles, we first tried to reproduce the hydrothermal synthetic conditions described for BaMnO3, varying the different experimental parameters as KOH and metal salts concentrations or temperature and pressure in the reaction vessel. Although the samples prepared correspond to the single 4H-SrMnO3 phase, they were always obtained as microparticles or microrods. Thus, the hydrothermal method does not seem to be adequate to get single crystalline nanoparticles of this phase.

elements.content: Thermal decomposition of a precursor material can be a promising alternative method to the hydrothermal one. This synthetic route has some advantages over other preparation methods such as simple procedures, low cost and easiness to obtain high purity products. The difficulty consists in preparing the appropriate precursor material, a homogeneous single phase that, upon decomposition, would yield the desired product. The precursor material must present limited thermal stability and accurately controlled stoichiometry with cations in the desired ratio. To our knowledge, the only attempt to prepare 4H-SrMnO3 from the decomposition of a heterometallic complex [SrMn(C3H2O4)2(H2O)4] (C3H2O4 = malonate) has failed since only SrMnO3 microparticles were obtained; besides neither structural nor physical characterization of this material has been reported.

This synthetic route has some advantages over other preparation methods such as simple procedures, low cost and easiness to obtain high purity products. The difficulty consists in preparing the appropriate precursor material, a homogeneous single phase that, upon decomposition, would yield the desired product. The precursor material must present limited thermal stability and accurately controlled stoichiometry with cations in the desired ratio. To our knowledge, the only attempt to prepare 4H-SrMnO3 from the decomposition of a heterometallic complex [SrMn(C3H2O4)2(H2O)4] (C3H2O4 = malonate) has failed since only SrMnO3 microparticles were obtained; besides neither structural nor physical characterization of this material has been reported.

elements.content: In this paper, we report the successful synthesis of single crystalline 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles prepared from a new starting material, [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]·3/2H2O (edta = ethylenediaminetetraacetate ion). The thermal decomposition of this heterometallic precursor has led to nanoparticles with average size around 70 nm. The small particle size increases drastically the reactivity of SrMnO3.0, so it can be topotactically reduced down to SrMnO2.82 without noticeable structural changes, showing very different behavior to that described for bulk SrMnO3. We also report the characterization of the precursor material as well as the structural and magnetic studies of both SrMnO3.0 and SrMnO2.82 nano-oxides.

The thermal decomposition of this heterometallic precursor has led to nanoparticles with average size around 70 nm. The small particle size increases drastically the reactivity of SrMnO3.0, so it can be topotactically reduced down to SrMnO2.82 without noticeable structural changes, showing very different behavior to that described for bulk SrMnO3. We also report the characterization of the precursor material as well as the structural and magnetic studies of both SrMnO3.0 and SrMnO2.82 nano-oxides.

elements.content: H4edta (7.305 g, 25 mmol) and MnCO3 (2.875 g, 25 mmol) were added to 300 mL of water. The mixture was refluxed for 20 h with stirring until it turned into a colorless solution. SrCO3 (3.690 g, 25 mmol) was then added to the warmed solution that was stirred for two more hours. The obtained solution was left overnight at room temperature observing the formation of a solid impurity that was removed by filtration. The remaining solution was slowly evaporated at room temperature for three weeks, affording white microcrystals with a 40% yield. Anal. calcd. for C10H25MnN2O14.5Sr (547.87): C, 23.06; H 4.30; N 5.20. Found: C, 21.92; H, 4.42; N 5.11%. elements.clean_text:
Experimental Methods

Synthesis of the Heterometallic Precursor Material [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]⋅3/2H2O

H4edta (7.305 g, 25 mmol) and MnCO3 (2.875 g, 25 mmol) were added to 300 mL of water. The mixture was refluxed for 20 h with stirring until it turned into a colorless solution. SrCO3 (3.690 g, 25 mmol) was then added to the warmed solution that was stirred for two more hours. The obtained solution was left overnight at room temperature observing the formation of a solid impurity that was removed by filtration. The remaining solution was slowly evaporated at room temperature for three weeks, affording white microcrystals with a 40% yield. Anal. calcd. for C10H25MnN2O14.5Sr (547.87): C, 23.06; H 4.30; N 5.20. Found: C, 21.92; H, 4.42; N 5.11%. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) = 3598(m), 3436(br), 2964(w), 2921(w), 1620(vs), 1600(vs), 1563(vs), 1462(m), 1446(m), 1414(s), 1394(s), 1343(m), 1322(m), 1295(w), 1255(m), 1242(w), 1134(w), 1110(m), 1028(w), 1012(w), 977(m), 963(w), 926(m), 862(w), 729(m), 713(m), 648(w), 591(w), 527(m), 481(w), 456(w).

elements.content: 4H-SrMnO3 is obtained as the final product of the thermal decomposition of [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]·3/2H2O at 1173 K in flowing oxygen by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Following this study and, in order to obtain pure 4H-phase, we have prepared brown polycrystalline SrMnO3.0 by heating the precursor in a tubular furnace at 1123 K for 4 h under oxygen atmosphere.
elements.clean_text:
Formation of 4H-SrMnO3 Nanomaterial

4H-SrMnO3 is obtained as the final product of the thermal decomposition of [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]⋅3/2H2O at 1173 K in flowing oxygen by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Following this study and, in order to obtain pure 4H-phase, we have prepared brown polycrystalline SrMnO3.0 by heating the precursor in a tubular furnace at 1123 K for 4 h under oxygen atmosphere.

elements.content: The oxygen content of this sample was determined by thermogravimetric analysis in a thermobalance CAHN D-200 heating the 4H-oxide to 973 K in 0.3 bar H2/ 0.2 bar He atmosphere. The green final products were identified by XRD as SrO and MnO and the weight loss observed agrees with the SrMnO3.0 composition.

elements.content:
The reduction process was performed in a thermobalance CAHN D-200 at 493 K under 0.2 bar H2/ 0.3 bar He atmosphere from 4H-SrMnO3.

Infrared (IR) Characterization

IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Thermo Nicolet 200 FT-IR spectrophotometer.

Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction

A colorless [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]·3/2H2O crystal (0.2 × 0.16 × 0.06 mm size) was resin-epoxy coated and mounted on a Bruker Smart CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.071073 nm) operating at 50 kV and 25 mA. Data were collected over a reciprocal space hemisphere by combination of three exposure sets. Each frame exposure time was 20 s covering 0.3° in ω. The cell parameters were determined and refined by least-squares fit of all reflections collected. The first 50 frames were recollected at the end of the data collection to monitor crystal decay, and no appreciable decay was observed. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by applying full-matrix least-squares on F2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were included with fixed isotropic contributions at their calculated positions determined by molecular geometry; except for the water hydrogen atoms, which were located on successive difference Fourier maps and refined riding on the corresponding oxygen atoms. All the calculations were carried out with the SHELX97 software package. After refining, the presence of solvent residual electron density was detected as disordered atomic groups located in the void regions and centered in sites among the molecules. The additional solvent water molecules could not be modeled properly due to its easy loss from the crystal. The program SQUEEZE, a part of the PLATON package of crystallographic software, was used to calculate the solvent disordered area and remove its contribution to the overall intensity data. An improvement was observed in all refinement parameters and residuals when this procedure was applied (CCDC depository no. 970551).

Data were collected over a reciprocal space hemisphere by combination of three exposure sets. Each frame exposure time was 20 s covering 0.3° in ω. The cell parameters were determined and refined by least-squares fit of all reflections collected. The first 50 frames were recollected at the end of the data collection to monitor crystal decay, and no appreciable decay was observed. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by applying full-matrix least-squares on F2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were included with fixed isotropic contributions at their calculated positions determined by molecular geometry; except for the water hydrogen atoms, which were located on successive difference Fourier maps and refined riding on the corresponding oxygen atoms. All the calculations were carried out with the SHELX97 software package. After refining, the presence of solvent residual electron density was detected as disordered atomic groups located in the void regions and centered in sites among the molecules. The additional solvent water molecules could not be modeled properly due to its easy loss from the crystal. The program SQUEEZE, a part of the PLATON package of crystallographic software, was used to calculate the solvent disordered area and remove its contribution to the overall intensity data. Powder X-ray Diffraction (XRD)

XRD patterns were collected using Cu Kα1 monochromatic radiation (λ = 0.154056 nm) at room temperature on a Panalytical X́PERT PRO MPD diffractometer equipped with a germanium 111 primary beam monochromator and X'Celerator fast detector.

elements.content: Thermal stability of the metal–organic precursor was performed in oxygen with a heating ratio of 5 K min–1 by using a SII TG/DTA6300 thermogravimetric analyzer. The overall oxygen content was determined by TGA using a CAHN D-200 electrobalance, which allows the determination of oxygen content variation within ±1.10–3 on a sample of about 100 mg working under 0.5 bar atmosphere. Experiments were performed by reduction under 0.3 bar H2/ 0.2 bar He atmosphere with a heating rate of 6 K min–1 up to 973 K. The oxygen content was determined from the weight difference between starting and final products.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

Thermal stability of the metal-organic precursor was performed in oxygen with a heating ratio of 5 K min-1 by using a SII TG/DTA6300 thermogravimetric analyzer. The overall oxygen content was determined by TGA using a CAHN D-200 electrobalance, which allows the determination of oxygen content variation within ±1.10-3 on a sample of about 100 mg working under 0.5 bar atmosphere. Experiments were performed by reduction under 0.3 bar H2/ 0.2 bar He atmosphere with a heating rate of 6 K min-1 up to 973 K. The oxygen content was determined from the weight difference between starting and final products.

elements.content:
The morphological study was carried out on a JEOL JSM6335-FEG scanning electron microscope operating at an acceleration voltage of 5 kV.

Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM and Energy Electron Loss Spectroscopy (EELS))

Selected Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) and High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) were performed on a JEOL 300FEG electron microscope. Chemical composition of the nanocrystals was determined by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) in both JEOL JSM6335-FEG and JEOL 300FEG electron microscopes. Atomic resolution characterization was performed on a JEOL JEM-ARM200cF electron microscope (Cold Emission Gun) operating at 200 kV provided with a spherical aberration corrector in probe (current emission density ∼1.4 × 10–9 A and probe size ∼0.08 nm), a GIF-QuantumER spectrometer and an Oxford INCA-350 detector.
elements.clean_text:
Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM)

The morphological study was carried out on a JEOL JSM6335-FEG scanning electron microscope operating at an acceleration voltage of 5 kV.

Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM and Energy Electron Loss Spectroscopy (EELS))

Selected Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) and High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) were performed on a JEOL 300FEG electron microscope. Chemical composition of the nanocrystals was determined by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) in both JEOL JSM6335-FEG and JEOL 300FEG electron microscopes. Atomic resolution characterization was performed on a JEOL JEM-ARM200cF electron microscope (Cold Emission Gun) operating at 200 kV provided with a spherical aberration corrector in probe (current emission density ~1.4 × 10-9 A and probe size ~0.08 nm), a GIF-QuantumER spectrometer and an Oxford INCA-350 detector.

elements.content: Magnetic experiments were performed on polycrystalline samples using a SQUID magnetometer MPMS XL-5 manufactured by Quantum Design. The temperature dependence of the magnetization for the precursor material was recorded in the range between 2 and 300 K using a constant magnetic field of 0.1 T. The experimental data were corrected for the magnetization of the sample holder (gelatin) and for atomic diamagnetism as calculated from the known Pascal’s constants. DC and AC magnetization measurements were performed in the temperature range 2–400 K.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Characterization

Magnetic experiments were performed on polycrystalline samples using a SQUID magnetometer MPMS XL-5 manufactured by Quantum Design. The temperature dependence of the magnetization for the precursor material was recorded in the range between 2 and 300 K using a constant magnetic field of 0.1 T. The experimental data were corrected for the magnetization of the sample holder (gelatin) and for atomic diamagnetism as calculated from the known Pascal's constants. DC and AC magnetization measurements were performed in the temperature range 2-400 K.

elements.content: The synthesis of nanocrystalline SrMnO3 from thermal decomposition of a molecular precursor requires the use of a heteronuclear coordination compound with the desired cationic ratio (1:1) which decomposes at low temperatures to prevent particle sintering from a prolonged heating. This is a necessary but not sufficient condition since, as previously mentioned, attempts to get nanoparticles from thermal decomposition of [SrMn(C3H2O4)(H2O)4] have failed showing that the chemical nature of the ligands can be an important factor in this chemical process. In this sense, the use of a more voluminous ligand, such edta, which can decompose more easily due to a higher steric hindrance in its coordination complexes, would be required. This fact induces the formation of Sr/Mn nuclei at lower temperatures and, therefore, prevents particle growth of the sought species. On the basis of these ideas, a new heterometallic [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]./2H2O complex has been successfully prepared as precursor of the 4H-oxide.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The synthesis of nanocrystalline SrMnO3 from thermal decomposition of a molecular precursor requires the use of a heteronuclear coordination compound with the desired cationic ratio (1:1) which decomposes at low temperatures to prevent particle sintering from a prolonged heating. This is a necessary but not sufficient condition since, as previously mentioned, attempts to get nanoparticles from thermal decomposition of [SrMn(C3H2O4)(H2O)4] have failed showing that the chemical nature of the ligands can be an important factor in this chemical process. In this sense, the use of a more voluminous ligand, such edta, which can decompose more easily due to a higher steric hindrance in its coordination complexes, would be required. This fact induces the formation of Sr/Mn nuclei at lower temperatures and, therefore, prevents particle growth of the sought species. On the basis of these ideas, a new heterometallic [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]./2H2O complex has been successfully prepared as precursor of the 4H-oxide.

elements.content: The title compound has been obtained following the synthetic pathway described in the part. This compound crystallizes in the P1̅ space group in the form of a two-dimensional coordination polymer. In this structure the Mn2+ ions are seven coordinated by one edta ligand (six coordination sites) and one water molecule in the form of a distorted pentagonal bipyramid. The Sr2+ ions are nine coordinated by five oxygen atoms corresponding to three different edta ligands and four water molecules forming Sr dimers by sharing one edge in their coordination polyhedra. The edta ligand is bridging the Mn and Sr ions in a complex network supported by several hydrogen bonds involving the water molecules present in the crystal (Figure ). There is a void space between the sheets in which additional water molecules can be accommodated. These water molecules can easily leave the channels leading to the loss of solvent water observed for this compound. The additional water molecules have been eliminated in the crystal structure description by the use of the SQUEEZE program, but they are clearly seen in the thermal decomposition experiment.
elements.clean_text:
[SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]⋅3/2H2O Heterometallic Precursor

The title compound has been obtained following the synthetic pathway described in the  part. This compound crystallizes in the P1̅ space group in the form of a two-dimensional coordination polymer. In this structure the Mn2+ ions are seven coordinated by one edta ligand (six coordination sites) and one water molecule in the form of a distorted pentagonal bipyramid. The Sr2+ ions are nine coordinated by five oxygen atoms corresponding to three different edta ligands and four water molecules forming Sr dimers by sharing one edge in their coordination polyhedra. The edta ligand is bridging the Mn and Sr ions in a complex network supported by several hydrogen bonds involving the water molecules present in the crystal (Figure ). There is a void space between the sheets in which additional water molecules can be accommodated. These water molecules can easily leave the channels leading to the loss of solvent water observed for this compound. The additional water molecules have been eliminated in the crystal structure description by the use of the SQUEEZE program, but they are clearly seen in the thermal decomposition experiment.

elements.content: The IR spectrum of this compound shows the characteristic bands of the edta carboxylate groups. Several ν(OCO) can be observed in the 1620–1563 cm–1 and 1446–1394 cm–1 regions, corresponding to the different coordinated carboxylate groups observed in the crystal structure.

elements.content: The thermal decomposition process for the edta complex of Mn and Sr was studied by TGA in flowing oxygen for a freshly prepared sample (Figure ). The decomposition steps can be explained as three consecutive processes: dehydration, ligand pyrolysis, and SrMnO3 formation. The first step (22.7%) occurs in the temperature range 323–408 K and corresponds to the loss of the 8.5 water molecules. The second step occurs around 543 K and corresponds to the ligand pyrolysis. It is important to note that this decomposition occurs as an abrupt step at a temperature around 80 K below the observed decomposition of the analogous malonate derivative described in the literature in accordance with the proposed lower stability of the edta ligand.

It is important to note that this decomposition occurs as an abrupt step at a temperature around 80 K below the observed decomposition of the analogous malonate derivative described in the literature in accordance with the proposed lower stability of the edta ligand.

elements.content: The weight loss (44.6%) agrees with the edta decomposition and the loss of five coordination water molecules, and it is in accordance with the formation of the SrCO3 and Mn3O4, identified by XRD, as decarboxylation products. This plateau remains stable until temperature close to 873 K. Finally, a small weight loss (4.4%) corresponds to the formation of 4H-SrMnO3, identified by powder XRD. The total weight loss in the decomposition process, 71.7%, agrees with the decomposition of the above-mentioned [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]·3/2H2O having an excess of seven water molecules. Those additional water molecules correspond to the disordered solvent molecules, described in the crystal structure discussion, which are easily lost by the sample when left at room temperature. No significant changes in the final product obtained have been found when the TGA study conditions, as the heating rate or the use of nitrogen atmosphere, were changed. Further structural and magnetic characterization of this compound is available in .

4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles were obtained from thermal decomposition of the above precursor (thermogravimetric study included in ). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern (see Figure S3a in ) can be fully indexed on the basis of a 4H-phase with parameters a = 0.5454(3) nm, c = 0.9112(6) nm. elements.content: In order to understand the formation of these nanoparticles, a SEM study of both the precursor and the obtained SrMnO3.0 has been performed. Figure a shows an image of the corresponding metal–organic precursor exhibiting an agglomeration of needle-shaped particles around 5–15 μm in length. After decomposition process, highly homogeneous SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles with average size 70 nm maintain the particle packing of the precursor leading to a sheet-assembling morphology (Figure b). A more detailed study of this assembling in terms of particle size shows that nanoparticles in the range 30–140 nm (Figure c) are observed, with the main particle size fraction between 40 and 100 nm (inset Figure c).

elements.content: Figure a shows a low magnification TEM image of a representative SrMnO3.0 nanoparticle. The corresponding Selected Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) patterns along [010] and [110] are shown in Figure b and c, respectively. The reflection conditions are consistent with the previous 4H-hexagonal cell and the sharp maxima observed indicate lack of significant concentration of structural defects. The HRTEM image along the [010] zone axis directly reveals contrast variation corresponding to the 4H (hchc)-stacking sequence (see Figure S5a in ). However, different contrast periodicity is observed in some areas of the nanoparticles (pointed by arrows in Figure a) indicating the presence of stacking faults in small areas. A detailed study of these areas has been performed.

elements.content: Figure a shows the atomically resolved high angle annular dark field (HAADF) image along [010]. The variation in HAADF signal intensity for each atomic column reflects the difference in atomic numbers between Mn (Z = 25) and Sr (Z = 38) cations, the brighter contrast corresponding to the heaviest Sr cations. Although the 4H-periodic alternation between cubic and hexagonal layers is observed in the main area of the material, extra cubic layers are clearly identified, confirming the presence of stacking faults in small regions of the nanoparticles. These defects can be associated to the presence of edge dislocations along the perpendicular crystallographic [2–10] direction, as observed in the corresponding two-beam Bright Field (BF) image acquired to reveal these one-dimensional defects (Figure b). This kind of structural defects are usually present in nanoparticles in such a way that, as the particle size decreases, the increasing number of surface and interface atoms generates stress/strain and concomitant structural perturbations.

elements.content: In order to study whether the edge dislocations are associated to changes of local composition with respect to the average SrMn4+O3.0 one, energy electron loss spectroscopy (EELS) characterization has been performed. These analyses confirm that Mn is only present as Mn4+ in all areas of the crystal (detailed EELS study in ). This result shows that the presence of edge dislocations is not associated to chemical composition variations through the nanoparticle.

elements.content: As we have mentioned in the introduction, the ratio of cubic/hexagonal layers and thus the corner-sharing/face-sharing octahedra, can be related to the tolerance factor (t). For a given polytype, the introduction of oxygen vacancies leads to a reduction of the B cation oxidation state which is associated with an increase in the B–O distances lowering the tolerance factor value and increasing the cubic/hexagonal layers ratio. Therefore, the structural type adopted by a determined phase is strongly coupled to the oxidation state of the transition metal.
elements.clean_text:
4H-SrMnO2.82 

As we have mentioned in the introduction, the ratio of cubic/hexagonal layers and thus the corner-sharing/face-sharing octahedra, can be related to the tolerance factor (t). For a given polytype, the introduction of oxygen vacancies leads to a reduction of the B cation oxidation state which is associated with an increase in the B-O distances lowering the tolerance factor value and increasing the cubic/hexagonal layers ratio. Therefore, the structural type adopted by a determined phase is strongly coupled to the oxidation state of the transition metal.

elements.content: The introduction of oxygen vacancies in the 4H-SrMnO3 bulk material usually requires extreme reduction conditions (vacuum, H2 atmosphere) and high temperatures around 1308–1623 K. Under these conditions, a cubic phase is always stabilized according to the decrease of the t value due to the partial substitution of Mn4+ by Mn3+. It reflects the coupling between the transition metal oxidation state and the stabilized structure at high temperature. However, when reduction reaction has been performed at low temperature, the oxide ions can be removed with almost no alteration of the cationic sublattice. In this way, some metastable phases have been stabilized by low temperature topochemical reduction of complex transition metal oxides with binary metal hydrides.

It reflects the coupling between the transition metal oxidation state and the stabilized structure at high temperature. However, when reduction reaction has been performed at low temperature, the oxide ions can be removed with almost no alteration of the cationic sublattice. In this way, some metastable phases have been stabilized by low temperature topochemical reduction of complex transition metal oxides with binary metal hydrides.

elements.content: The small particle size of the as prepared 4H-SrMnO3.0 increases its reactivity lowering significantly the reaction temperature and, therefore, breaking the coupling between the average Mn oxidation state and the stabilized structure. The reduction process takes place under very soft conditions (493 K) and the 4H structure is retained down to a SrMnO2.82 composition as can be seen in the XRD pattern (Figure S3b in ). Although the particle size is slightly increased due to the annealing during the reduction process, a homogeneous particle size distribution is achieved and size is kept within the nanometric scale with an average size of 100 nm (Figure ).

elements.content: Motivated by the fact that the hexagonal-related structure is retained even with more than 6% of oxygen vacancies per unit formula and, in order to understand the topotactic pathway of the cubic layers insertion in the reduction process, the most refined spatial resolution techniques become essential for the complete microstructural characterization of SrMnO2.82, to determine the role that oxygen vacancies play in the hexagonal to cubic layers transformation. This microstructural study has been performed by atomically resolved imaging and analytical tools associated with TEM. SAED patterns along [010] and [110] of a representative SrMnO2.82 nanoparticle are shown in Figures a and b. Again, diffraction maxima can be indexed on the basis of a 4H-hexagonal unit cell in agreement with XRD data, but the clear streaking observed along c*-axis indicates a more disordered microstructure compared to the nonoxygen deficient 4H-SrMnO3.0 sample. The corresponding [010] HRTEM image of a SrMnO2.82 nanoparticle in Figure c reveals the presence of a high concentration of extra cubic layers breaking the 4H-stacking sequence along c-axis in the whole nanoparticle. This feature makes a clear difference with respect to the SrMnO3.0 sample where extra cubic layers were only found in isolated small regions of the particles. Oxygen deficiency in 4H-SrMnO2.82 necessarily leads to an increase of Mn3+ content in the structure. The size difference between Mn3+ (0.058 nm LS; 0.0645 nm HS) and Mn4+ (0.0530 nm) cations would promote the location of larger Mn3+ in cubic layers, suggesting that the decrease of the oxygen content contributes to the stabilization of cubic layers in SrMnO2.82. From the contrast of the HRTEM image of a SrMnO2.82 nanoparticle, additional extended structural defects are observed, marked by arrows in Figure c, which cannot be understood as the edge dislocations identified for the 4H-SrMnO3.0 sample. In fact, the lack of edge dislocations may be explained considering that the increase of c-layers, that is, the increase of corner-sharing octahedra, provides flexibility to the structural skeleton thus relieving the strain/stress within the nanoparticles.

elements.content: Figure a shows the atomically resolved HAADF image along [010] of a representative structural defect in the SrMnO2.82 nanoparticle revealing the disposition of the Sr and Mn columns. Following the a-axis, the contrast variation of the image shows that the defect areas are associated to the transformation of hexagonal into cubic layers giving rise to ...ccc... blocks corresponding to three corner-sharing octahedra (pointed with blue arrows). These ...ccc... structural blocks are formed in opposite ends of the defect (A and B areas in Figure a). Between the two new generated cubic layers, a cationic disorder is observed covering two 4H unit cells marked with yellow lines in Figure a. The structural change takes place by the slight movement of the Sr columns toward the closest oxygen sites as schematically represented in model ① in Figure b.

elements.content: Such cationic arrangement can be followed in the enlarged [010] HAADF image in Figure c. As it can be observed, extra atomic columns progressively become visible close to the brighter Sr ones resulting into two sets of cationic columns in a very short separation distance (around 0.12 nm projected distance). This indicates that Sr atoms which should be occupying only the starting position are now shifted along a-axis over two very close positions observed in the image (see model ② in Figure b).

elements.content: The displacement of Sr atoms toward oxygen sites seems to indicate that anionic positions should be, at least, partially unoccupied in the reduced phase. This is confirmed by the corresponding [010] annular bright field (ABF) image in Figure d where the location of the oxygen columns is revealed as the less dark contrast while cationic information is still present, in such a way that the heaviest elements show the darker contrast. The contrast variation along the marked yellow row corresponds to the alternation of one Mn and one oxygen atomic columns. In the defect area, this ordered situation is abruptly broken and a succession of much stronger contrast shows instead. This feature evidence that Sr is displaced toward the neighbor oxygen position occupying the empty sites generated by the reduction process. As a result of this shift, the hexagonal layers that limit the defect area, marked in blue, become cubic. The subtle Sr delocalization is associated to a cooperative movement of the Mn columns in order to minimize the cationic repulsions and to preserve the stability of the 4H framework.

elements.content: As we have mentioned before, the Mn3+ is more likely accommodated in the cubic layers of the structure so a higher Mn3+ content is expected in the defect area. The distribution of Mn3+ and Mn4+ in the defect and defect-free areas of the nanoparticle has been determined by high energy resolution EELS (Figure S9 in ). Data analysis confirms higher Mn3+ content in the areas where the structural defects are observed (47% estimated Mn3+), while lower Mn3+ presence is found in defects free areas (17% estimated Mn3+) (see details in ).

elements.content: On the basis of the above results, the mechanism of the incorporation of cubic layers during the 4H-SrMnO3.0 → 4H-SrMnO2.82 reduction can be explained. Although the insertion of cubic layers in bulk hexagonal perovskites has been previously established as a mechanism of anion vacancies accommodation (see Figure S4 in ), the use of local probe techniques allows observing the pathway of such process in the corresponding nanoparticles. The generation of anionic vacancies in SrO3 layers enables the displacement along a-axis of the Sr atoms toward the closest oxygen positions, which are partially unoccupied in reduced SrMnO2.82. This provokes the delocalization of Sr atoms over two close sites. To minimize the resulting cationic repulsions, a rearrangement of the Mn atoms occurs. This progressive structural atomic rearrangement transforms the hexagonal layers into cubic ones preserving the 4H structural framework even with the incorporation of Mn3+. This complex process involving both sublattices is here seen for the first time by virtue of atomically resolved microscopy techniques.

elements.content: Bulk SrMnO3 exhibits two antiferromagnetic (AFM) transitions at T = 350 and 278 K that correspond to the AFM alignment of the spin restricted to face-sharing octahedra dimers and the three-dimensionalization of this AFM order with the AFM coupling between hexagonal layers through the cubic corner-sharing units (see figure S4 in ). As the number of AFM pairs is very much the same, large anomalies are not expected around T = 278 K. Indeed, from magnetic susceptibility data only a large divergence between the Zero Field-Cooled (ZFC) and Field-Cooled (FC) runs is frequently reported. Several interactions are operating in the bulk system: competing ferromagnetic (FM) Mn–O–Mn 90° superexchange interactions (SE) and dominant AFM direct exchange interactions (DE) for Mn–Mn distances smaller than 0.25 nm between transition metals in the hexagonal subunits.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Bulk SrMnO3 exhibits two antiferromagnetic (AFM) transitions at T = 350 and 278 K that correspond to the AFM alignment of the spin restricted to face-sharing octahedra dimers and the three-dimensionalization of this AFM order with the AFM coupling between hexagonal layers through the cubic corner-sharing units (see figure S4 in ). As the number of AFM pairs is very much the same, large anomalies are not expected around T = 278 K. Indeed, from magnetic susceptibility data only a large divergence between the Zero Field-Cooled (ZFC) and Field-Cooled (FC) runs is frequently reported. Several interactions are operating in the bulk system: competing ferromagnetic (FM) Mn-O-Mn 90° superexchange interactions (SE) and dominant AFM direct exchange interactions (DE) for Mn-Mn distances smaller than 0.25 nm between transition metals in the hexagonal subunits.

elements.content: When decreasing the particle size down to the nanoscale, this basic picture is confirmed. Figure shows the ZFC-FC magnetization vs temperature. One transition is already apparent at T = 350 K and a large irreversibility appears at T = 275 K pointing out to the second Néel transition when the three-dimensionalization of the AFM interactions takes place. The latter manifest itself as a double maximum in the ZFC around T = 250 and 195 K, probably due to different transition temperatures for octahedra located in the surface and core of the nanoparticles (see inset Figure ). The Neel temperatures are depleted due to the nanosize of particles. An additional anomaly is observed in the temperature region around 45 K as well as paramagnetic tail at low temperatures. Adkin and Hayward also report on the existence of a paramagnetic like tail that it is ascribed to the presence of a small number of Mn(III) impurity centers not contributing to the temperature dependence of the magnetization.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of Downsizing on 4H-SrMnO3.0 

When decreasing the particle size down to the nanoscale, this basic picture is confirmed. Figure  shows the ZFC-FC magnetization vs temperature. One transition is already apparent at T = 350 K and a large irreversibility appears at T = 275 K pointing out to the second Néel transition when the three-dimensionalization of the AFM interactions takes place. The latter manifest itself as a double maximum in the ZFC around T = 250 and 195 K, probably due to different transition temperatures for octahedra located in the surface and core of the nanoparticles (see inset Figure ). The Neel temperatures are depleted due to the nanosize of particles. An additional anomaly is observed in the temperature region around 45 K as well as paramagnetic tail at low temperatures. Adkin and Hayward also report on the existence of a paramagnetic like tail that it is ascribed to the presence of a small number of Mn(III) impurity centers not contributing to the temperature dependence of the magnetization.

elements.content: In nanosized systems, it is expected that the AFM superexchange interactions relax on the surface layer promoting a surface phase segregation scenario where FM correlations are present in the outermost layers. The existence of such FM interactions within a spin-glass shell has been reported in related materials La0.7Ca0.3MnO3 and CaMnO3‑δ among others. Consequently, the low temperature anomaly could be related to some kind of spin-glass like transition. However, although spin disorder is clearly present in our samples, from our AC-measurements, a canonical spin glass cannot be solidly postulated (see ).

elements.content: In order to fully explore the successive transitions in the fully oxidized sample, we have also measured the isothermal magnetizations at relevant temperatures. Figure a shows the hysteresis cycles of SrMnO3.0. It basically compels to what it is expected for an AFM. A closer look (Figure a inset) points toward the existence of a very weak FM contribution at all measured temperatures that could correspond to the canting of the AFM coupled spins. However, at the lowest temperature, T = 5 K, the cycle opens up and resembles those reported for AFM in close contact with spin-glass-like patches, as it is indeed confirmed by the vertical exchange bias shift (see ).

elements.content: Regarding the reduced 4H-SrMnO2.82 sample, Figure shows the ZFC-FC temperature dependence of the magnetization measured at the same conditions as the fully oxidized sample. A large irreversibility develops at T = 200 K pointing out to a Néel transition at this temperature. A depletion of this transition could be expected if some stoichiometric very small clusters of fully oxidized 4H-SrMnO3.0 are still present in the reduced sample due to the randomness nature of the reduction process. In this direction, on lowering the temperature a broad feature develops in the background (see inset) compatible with a two-dimensional characteristic of a weak magnetic order. In this sense, a weak ferromagnetism could be accomplished by the presence of Mn3+–Mn4+ interactions through the apical oxygens in cubic layers. However, the most pronounced anomaly in Figure appears at T = 67 K. Since this anomaly is absent in the oxidized SrMnO3.0, it must be related to the lower manganese coordination units in the reduced sample after removal of oxygen ions. The Mn–Mn distances in Mn2O9–x dimers increase due to the presence of Mn3+ and, therefore, an increase of short ranged ferromagnetic interactions in these units is expected.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of Reduction on Nanostructured 4H-SrMnO3.0 

Regarding the reduced 4H-SrMnO2.82 sample, Figure  shows the ZFC-FC temperature dependence of the magnetization measured at the same conditions as the fully oxidized sample. A large irreversibility develops at T = 200 K pointing out to a Néel transition at this temperature. A depletion of this transition could be expected if some stoichiometric very small clusters of fully oxidized 4H-SrMnO3.0 are still present in the reduced sample due to the randomness nature of the reduction process. In this direction, on lowering the temperature a broad feature develops in the background (see inset) compatible with a two-dimensional characteristic of a weak magnetic order. In this sense, a weak ferromagnetism could be accomplished by the presence of Mn3+-Mn4+ interactions through the apical oxygens in cubic layers. However, the most pronounced anomaly in Figure  appears at T = 67 K. Since this anomaly is absent in the oxidized SrMnO3.0, it must be related to the lower manganese coordination units in the reduced sample after removal of oxygen ions. The Mn-Mn distances in Mn2O9-x  dimers increase due to the presence of Mn3+ and, therefore, an increase of short ranged ferromagnetic interactions in these units is expected.

elements.content: Figure b shows the isothermal behavior of the magnetization for the reduced sample. At 300 K the system is a pure paramagnet. It correlates with the absence of the high temperature Néel transition of the face-sharing octahedra subunits in the reduced sample, as these units are strongly modified due to the oxygen loss. A closer look in Figure b inset reveals that the cycle opens up at temperatures below Néel temperature and again the cycle at the lowest temperature points toward some kind of spin-glass-like behavior as it is confirmed by the observed vertical exchange bias shift reported in the . Note also the higher values attained by the magnetization at 50000 Oe when compared to the values registered for the fully oxidized sample. This could confirm the presence of additional FM interactions between new Mn3+ and Mn4+ pairs connecting the cubic and hexagonal structural units. This is also consistent with the existence of a paramagnetic tail that can be related to the presence of Mn(III) centers in the reduced samples.

elements.content: Thermal decomposition of molecular precursors has shown to be a very useful method to synthesize 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles from a new metal–organic compound with a voluminous and steric demanding ligand, [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]·3/2H2O. After decomposition, the 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles formed maintain the particle packing of the precursor material leading to a sheet-assembling morphology. The nanometric size of SrMnO3.0 particles enables the topotactic reduction of the sample maintaining the 4H structure down to SrMnO2.82. The use of aberration corrected electron microscopy has allowed us to obtain unveiling structural and compositional details with unprecedented information on the reduction mechanism. The reduced phase shows a very complex microstructure with high concentration of extra cubic layers breaking the 4H-sequence, leading to a local rearrangement of cubic and hexagonal layers in the defect area. High energy resolution EELS spectra reveal a higher concentration of Mn3+ in defect areas which induces the formation of extra cubic planes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Thermal decomposition of molecular precursors has shown to be a very useful method to synthesize 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles from a new metal-organic compound with a voluminous and steric demanding ligand, [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]⋅3/2H2O. After decomposition, the 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles formed maintain the particle packing of the precursor material leading to a sheet-assembling morphology. The nanometric size of SrMnO3.0 particles enables the topotactic reduction of the sample maintaining the 4H structure down to SrMnO2.82. The use of aberration corrected electron microscopy has allowed us to obtain unveiling structural and compositional details with unprecedented information on the reduction mechanism. The reduced phase shows a very complex microstructure with high concentration of extra cubic layers breaking the 4H-sequence, leading to a local rearrangement of cubic and hexagonal layers in the defect area. High energy resolution EELS spectra reveal a higher concentration of Mn3+ in defect areas which induces the formation of extra cubic planes.

elements.content: The nanometric size seems to strongly influence the magnetic properties since 4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles show a magnetic behavior clearly different to that observed in bulk material. Besides the AFM direct exchange interactions, a weak ferromagnetic contribution, associated to the canting of AFM coupled spins, is apparent at 45 K. At 5 K, the magnetic features correspond to an AFM system in close contact with a spin-glass like patches as confirmed by the vertical exchange bias. A large depletion of the Néel transition is observed in 4H-SrMnO2.82 probably due to the presence of nanoclusters of fully oxidized SrMnO3 still present into the reduced sample due to the randomness of the reduction process. Some magnetic anomalies are observed in the 40–60 K range ascribed to the promotion of ferromagnetic short-range interactions in the dimers resulting from the increase of the Mn–Mn distances.

Some magnetic anomalies are observed in the 40-60 K range ascribed to the promotion of ferromagnetic short-range interactions in the dimers resulting from the increase of the Mn-Mn distances.

H4edta (7.305 g, 25 mmol) and MnCO3 (2.875 g, 25 mmol) were added to 300 mL of water. The mixture was refluxed for 20 h with stirring until it turned into a colorless solution. SrCO3 (3.690 g, 25 mmol) was then added to the warmed solution that was stirred for two more hours. The obtained solution was left overnight at room temperature observing the formation of a solid impurity that was removed by filtration. The remaining solution was slowly evaporated at room temperature for three weeks, affording white microcrystals with a 40% yield. Anal. calcd. for C10H25MnN2O14.5Sr (547.87): C, 23.06; H 4.30; N 5.20. Found: C, 21.92; H, 4.42; N 5.11%. IR (KBr): ν (cm–1) = 3598(m), 3436(br), 2964(w), 2921(w), 1620(vs), 1600(vs), 1563(vs), 1462(m), 1446(m), 1414(s), 1394(s), 1343(m), 1322(m), 1295(w), 1255(m), 1242(w), 1134(w), 1110(m), 1028(w), 1012(w), 977(m), 963(w), 926(m), 862(w), 729(m), 713(m), 648(w), 591(w), 527(m), 481(w), 456(w).

Formation of 4H-SrMnO<sub>3</sub> Nanomaterial

4H-SrMnO3 is obtained as the final product of the thermal decomposition of [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]·3/2H2O at 1173 K in flowing oxygen by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Following this study and, in order to obtain pure 4H-phase, we have prepared brown polycrystalline SrMnO3.0 by heating the precursor in a tubular furnace at 1123 K for 4 h under oxygen atmosphere.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Methods

Synthesis of the Heterometallic Precursor Material [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]⋅3/2H2O

H4edta (7.305 g, 25 mmol) and MnCO3 (2.875 g, 25 mmol) were added to 300 mL of water. The mixture was refluxed for 20 h with stirring until it turned into a colorless solution. SrCO3 (3.690 g, 25 mmol) was then added to the warmed solution that was stirred for two more hours. The obtained solution was left overnight at room temperature observing the formation of a solid impurity that was removed by filtration. The remaining solution was slowly evaporated at room temperature for three weeks, affording white microcrystals with a 40% yield. Anal. calcd. for C10H25MnN2O14.5Sr (547.87): C, 23.06; H 4.30; N 5.20. Found: C, 21.92; H, 4.42; N 5.11%. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) = 3598(m), 3436(br), 2964(w), 2921(w), 1620(vs), 1600(vs), 1563(vs), 1462(m), 1446(m), 1414(s), 1394(s), 1343(m), 1322(m), 1295(w), 1255(m), 1242(w), 1134(w), 1110(m), 1028(w), 1012(w), 977(m), 963(w), 926(m), 862(w), 729(m), 713(m), 648(w), 591(w), 527(m), 481(w), 456(w).

Formation of 4H-SrMnO3 Nanomaterial

4H-SrMnO3 is obtained as the final product of the thermal decomposition of [SrMn(edta)(H2O)5]⋅3/2H2O at 1173 K in flowing oxygen by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Following this study and, in order to obtain pure 4H-phase, we have prepared brown polycrystalline SrMnO3.0 by heating the precursor in a tubular furnace at 1123 K for 4 h under oxygen atmosphere.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal decomposition process for the edta complex of Mn and Sr was studied by TGA in flowing oxygen for a freshly prepared sample (Figure ). The decomposition steps can be explained as three consecutive processes: dehydration, ligand pyrolysis, and SrMnO3 formation. The first step (22.7%) occurs in the temperature range 323–408 K and corresponds to the loss of the 8.5 water molecules. The second step occurs around 543 K and corresponds to the ligand pyrolysis. It is important to note that this decomposition occurs as an abrupt step at a temperature around 80 K below the observed decomposition of the analogous malonate derivative described in the literature in accordance with the proposed lower stability of the edta ligand.

4H-SrMnO<sub>3.0</sub>

4H-SrMnO3.0 nanoparticles were obtained from thermal decomposition of the above precursor (thermogravimetric study included in ). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern (see Figure S3a in ) can be fully indexed on the basis of a 4H-phase with parameters a = 0.5454(3) nm, c = 0.9112(6) nm. The symmetry and lattice parameters are consistent with bulk values (a = 0.54434(2) nm, c = 0.90704(1) nm, P63/mmc).

metadata.title:
Synthesis of 4H-SrMnO3.0 Nanoparticles
from a Molecular Precursor and Their Topotactic Reduction Pathway
Identified at Atomic Scale
